description: From Middle English mayntenen, from Old French maintenir, from Late Latin manūteneō, manūtenēre (“I support”), from Latin manū (“with the hand”) + teneō (“I hold”).

verbs.description: maintain (third-person singular simple present maintains, present participle maintaining, simple past and past participle maintained)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To support (someone), to back up or assist (someone) in an action. [14th–19th c.]
To keep up; to preserve; to uphold (a state, condition etc.). [from 14th c.]
To declare or affirm (a clause) to be true; to assert. [from 15th c.]
To keep in good condition and working order.
